current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title 11 and title 29, United States Code, to increase the amount of unsecured claims for
			 salaries and wages given priority in bankruptcy, to provide for
			 payments to retirees to compensate for lost health insurance benefits
			 resulting from the bankruptcy of their former employer, to protect the
			 health benefits of employees and retirees, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Bankruptcy Fairness and Employee Benefits Protection Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Bankruptcy Fairness and Employee Benefits Protection Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: TITLE I—Fairness for employees and retirees in corporate bankruptcies
Sec. 101. Prohibition of unfair reductions to employee and retiree benefits.
Sec. 102. Payment of insurance benefits to retirees.
Sec. 105. Protection of benefits in chapter 9 bankruptcy.
Sec. 106. Requirement to make pension contributions.
TITLE II—Protection of employee and retiree health benefits
Sec. 201. Notification of extent to which health benefits can be modified or terminated.
Sec. 202. Protection of retirees under certain collectively bargained agreements.

header.#text: Presumption that retired employee health benefits cannot be modified or terminated

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
), the presumption for
			 purposes of such suit shall be that as of the date an employee retires or
			 completes 20 years of service with the employer, benefits
			 available under the plan during retirement of the employee are fully
			 vested and cannot be modified or terminated for the life of the employee
			 or, if longer, the life of the employee's spouse. This presumption can be
			 overcome only upon a showing, by clear and convincing evidence, that the
			 terms of the group health plan allow for a modification or termination of
			 benefits available under the plan and that the employee, prior to becoming
			 a participant in the plan, was made aware, in clear and unambiguous terms,
			 that the plan allowed for such modification or termination of benefits.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974/s:733/ss:a/p:1

			 group health plan (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 8 of the National Labor Relations
			 Act

header.#text:
Protection of
			 retirees under certain collectively bargained agreements

text.#text:
It shall be an
				unfair labor practice for any labor organization and any employer
			 to enter into
				any contract or agreement, express or implied, whereby the
			 organization and
				employer agree to modify the terms of any previous agreement in a
			 manner that
				would result in a reduction or termination of retiree health
			 insurance benefits provided to an employee or a dependent of an employee
			 under the previous agreement, if such modification of the terms of the
			 previous agreement occurs after the date
			 on which the employee retires.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Comptroller General of the
			 United
			 States

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a report on the strategies that
			 corporations
			 use to avoid obligations to pay promised employee and retiree benefits.

text.#text:
Not later than 180 days
			 after the date of enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Bankruptcy Fairness and Employee Benefit Protection Act of 2014/s:203/ss:a

text.#text:
the use of
			 spin-offs, mergers, subsidiaries, bankruptcies, asset sales, and other
			 strategies to avoid obligations to pay promised employee and retiree
			 benefits;

the impact of
			 such avoidance on the financial, physical, and mental well-being of
			 employees
			 and retirees;

the impact on
			 Federal and State budgets when employers terminate or reduce the benefits
			 of
			 employees and retirees, including the costs that are incurred when
			 employees and retirees seek
			 assistance from Federal and State government programs and services as a
			 result of the termination or reduction of their employment-related
			 benefits; and

recommendations
			 to prevent corporations from evading contractual obligations to pay
			 employee
			 and retiree benefits.

header.#text:
Protection of employee and retiree health
			 benefits
